title: Research & Fellowships
text:
Overview:  Developed familiarity with RISC-V microprocessor design, verification, and certification workflows through analysis of open-source CORE-V Wally architecture and RISC-V specifications.
Worked with Python, SystemVerilog, and RISC-V assembly concepts to design tests, explore coverage metrics, and understand microprocessor verification methodologies.
Applied instruction-set simulation, SystemVerilog simulation, and coverage analysis techniques to understand RISC-V specifications, debug test behavior, and evaluate microprocessor verification workflows.




 


Overview:  Designed and tested low-noise, field-deployable analog amplifiers for electropenetrography (EPG) to monitor feeding behavior of disease-vector insects, supporting agricultural and ecological research.
Developed microcontroller firmware and Python-based software to acquire, process, and visualize high-sensitivity analog signals from insect feeding experiments.
Applied benchtop electronics skills including oscilloscopes, function generators, and power supplies to prototype circuits, optimize signal quality, and improve reliability for field deployment.




 


Overview:  Operated and programmed a large hexacopter drone carrying a custom (Xilinx FPGA) RF transmitter to calibrate and map a clear beam pattern of a ground-based radio telescope, modeling a software defined radio.
Developed FPGA-based software-defined radio system with Verilog and Python, transmitting and receiving GHz-wideband signals for DSP analysis via Fast Fourier Transforms (FFTs).
Configured hardware and software systems include drone flight control (PX4/Ardupilot) GPS synchronization, RF amplification, and Python–based data analysis/visualization.

title: Joaquin Gonzalez-Salgado
text:
Welcome to my Engineering Portfolio! I am a rising Junior Engineering major at Harvey Mudd College interested in electrical and computer engineering (with appreciation for mechanical engineering.) I’m currently doing research developing an open source RISC-V verification suite for the CORE-V Wally Processor under the Clay-Wolkin Fellowship. I also work alongside the USDA as a hardware/firmware engineer focused on creating low-noise analog amplifiers for monitoring insect feeding behavior as part of the Analog Circuitry Engineering (ACE) Lab.

title: Personal & Class Projects
text:
Team project to build an electric vehicle. Principles of EV design, battery technology, vehicle dynamics, fabrication, wiring, and embedded software development.
Coming Soon!





Designing a Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) to map collect water-characteristic data at Dana Point Harbor, CA.
Coming Soon!






 


Overview:  Developed an embedded C application to implement a 2D digital level, interfacing a triple-axis accelerometer with a microcontroller to measure tilt along the x and y axes.
Designed and wired a complete hardware system on a breadboard, integrating a RED-V development board, LIS3DH accelerometer, and an 8×8 LED matrix.
Processed sensor data and controlled peripheral hardware, calibrating accelerometer readings, converting tilt angles into discrete LED positions, and driving the LED matrix.




 


Overview:  Designed a multicycle RISC-V processor in SystemVerilog, creating a hierarchical architecture with a finite-state machine, datapath, ALU, register file, and unified memory adapted from a single-cycle design.
Validated processor functionality through simulation and waveform analysis, tracking key signals, and control states to ensure correct multi-cycle instruction execution.
Systematically debugged RTL using testbenches and predicted execution traces, identifying and resolving interface mismatches, and control signal errors, until the processor passed all tests.







 


Overview:  Constructed an underwater remotely operated vehicle (ROV) used to retrieve temperature, pressure, and other signals in lake environments via the MCP9701 thermistor and MPX5700ASX pressure gauge.
Assembled a PCB containing the MCP6002 OpAmp to return output voltages that can be modeled and analyzed in LabView.
Also configured the thrusters, power regulation circuits, and user inputs with robust waterproofing considerations including wiring and motors.







 


Overview:  Designed and assembled a logic-gate demonstration board using 74HC Series integrated circuits, a 555 timer, and a potentiometer-based clock input.
Engineered intuitive controls with input switches, banana cables and ports for adjustability, and LEDs to clearly display output states.
Delivered a durable, lecture teaching tool now used by Professor Stone for the Digital Logic and Computer Architecture Course.




 


Overview:  Manufactured a precision machinist hammer from clear oak, AISI 1015 steel, AISI 4340 steel, and nylon, adhering to detailed engineering drawings, dimensional tolerances, and safety requirements.
The project emphasized material selection, fit, and functional performance. Applied a range of machining and fabrication processes, including turning and facing on manual lathes, milling operations, tapping, and controlled heat treatment using industrial ovens to achieve specified mechanical properties and final dimensions.
I now serve as a Machine Shop Proctor, responsible for training and supervising new engineering students in the step-by-step hammer manufacturing process, ensuring adherence to technical standards and best practices.
